description: From Middle English aland, alond, alonde, o lande, from Old English on lande (“on land”), equivalent to a- +‎ land.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) On dry land, as opposed to in the water. [13th–19th c.]
(now rare, poetic) To the land; ashore. [from 14th c.]
examples: Henry the Eighth  […]  departed out of England from Sowthampton, with a great navy of shipps to set that company aland in Spayne, for to helpe the kynge of Spayne agaynste the Frenche kynge  […]
